title: Interrupted block-sync finishing with panic error
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `1.5.5-stable`
OS & Version: OSX 10.11.6 (15G1108) on the MBA (13-inch, Late 2010)

#### Expected behaviour

Normal (without any errors) shutting down when got `ctrl+c` interrupt event.

#### Actual behaviour

Panic error when finishing block synchronisation after user's interrupt event (`ctrl+c`).

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

1. `geth`
1. wait full initialisation & start (line like `Block synchronisation started`)
1. `^C` (ctrl+c)
1. boom!

#### Backtrace

````
I0101 03:13:22.556662 core/blockchain.go:1047] imported 24 blocks,   334 txs ( 23.755 Mg) in    8.150s ( 2.915 Mg/s). #1743892 [42896f81… / 43e13fa6…]
^CI0101 03:13:24.806115 cmd/utils/cmd.go:83] Got interrupt, shutting down...
I0101 03:13:24.851444 node/node.go:373] IPC endpoint closed: /Users/ak/Library/Ethereum/geth.ipc
panic: sync: WaitGroup is reused before previous Wait has returned

goroutine 14304 [running]:
panic(0x486e3a0, 0xc42395e920)
	/usr/local/opt/go/libexec/src/runtime/panic.go:500 +0x1a1
sync.(*WaitGroup).Wait(0xc420220308)
	/usr/local/opt/go/libexec/src/sync/waitgroup.go:133 +0xfe
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/core.(*BlockChain).Stop(0xc420220240)
	/private/tmp/ethereum-20161230-26629-jkf72d/build/_workspace/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/core/blockchain.go:590 +0x9b
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/eth.(*Ethereum).Stop(0xc4201141c0, 0xc4246e2480, 0xc420dc1f28)
	/private/tmp/ethereum-20161230-26629-jkf72d/build/_workspace/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/eth/backend.go:439 +0x40
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/node.(*Node).Stop(0xc4203d0480, 0x0, 0x0)
	/private/tmp/ethereum-20161230-26629-jkf72d/build/_workspace/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/node/node.go:509 +0x1fb
created by github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/cmd/utils.StartNode.func1
	/private/tmp/ethereum-20161230-26629-jkf72d/build/_workspace/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/cmd/utils/cmd.go:84 +0x1cf
````

Yeah, that's a spurious issue that rarely occurs during shutdown. It's mostly harmless, just scary and ugly. Would be nice to fix, alas noone found the time to work on it.
